subject: Re: [junit] Setup inheritance
msgSnippet: Recently it was Professional Java XML Programming with Servlets and JSP by Alexander Nakhimovsky and Tom Myers.  After a week of pair programming, it became
messageBody:
Recently it was Professional Java XML Programming with
Servlets and JSP by Alexander Nakhimovsky and Tom
Myers. After a week of pair programming, it became
terribly irrelevant. It hasn't even turned out to be
a good source for looking little things up via the
index. The book looks brand new, still, after several
months of owning it. :( Ah well..maybe someday I'll
have a use for it.

You could also lump any and all of the Java
Certification books here as well. I bought one, we
started going through it (a group of us at work who
thought it might be useful) and it turned out to be
full of junk that you would either a) never use
because it's too complex or b) wouldn't need to
remember because of better reference material (i.e.
websites).

-Eric

--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
wrote:
> Yikes. I only worked with a beta version of WSAD --
> that is, before I
> left IBM -- so I ran into a few of its little bugs;
> but not that one.
> You have my sympathies in that.
>
> Which book has just disgusted you, then? Write me
> directly if you'd
> rather not embarrass anyone on the world stage.
>
> Chin up!
>
> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>
> On 2002-07-19 at 08:08 Eric Heikkila wrote:
>
> >Oh no, of course not ;)
> >
> >Actually, I just had IBM Websphere Studio
> Application
> >Developer delete a couple of my project directories
> >while I was in the middle of editting them, for no
> >apparent reason. Twice. So I'm in a bit of a
> mood.
> >
> >That, and I'm really tired of buying a book,
> starting
> >to read through it, realizing I know more than the
> >yahoo that wrote it (or, rather, more than he/she
> >included in the text), and toss it aside in
> disgust.
> >
> >-Eric
> >
> >--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
> >wrote:
> >> I probably meant "inheritance in Java," as in
> >> extends, implements,
> >> super and all that rot.
> >>
> >> You're not lumping me in with the "long-winded"
> are
> >> you? :)
> >>
> >> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
> >>
> >> On 2002-07-19 at 07:36 Eric Heikkila wrote:
> >>
> >> >Read up on inheritence? hehehe...funny. You
> can
> >> >probably sum it up in one sentence.
> >> >
> >> >Of course, then, the long-winded and/or
> 'teacher'
> >> (or
> >> >certifier) types out there would be out of a
> job.
> >> ;)
> >> >
> >> >-Eric
> >> >
> >> >--- "J. B. Rainsberger"
> <jbr@...>
> >> >wrote:
> >> >> Hm. I think our original poster just missed
> out
> >> on a
> >> >> chance to learn
> >> >> something.
> >> >>
> >> >> To the original poster: please read up on
> >> >> inheritance anyway -- if
> >> >> you're a student, then it's good for you to
> know
> >> >> about, and if you're a
> >> >> professional, people out there will assume you
> >> know
> >> >> it.
> >> >>
> >> >> Best of luck.
> >> >>
> >> >> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
> >> >>
> >> >> On 2002-07-18 at 15:46 Eric Heikkila wrote:
> >> >>
> >> >> >Shorter answer...
> >> >> >
> >> >> >... make sure you have something like the
> >> >> following:
> >> >> >
> >> >> >public BaseClass extends TestCase {
> >> >> >
> >> >> > public void setUp() {
> >> >> > System.out.println("BaseClass");
> >> >> > }
> >> >> >}
> >> >> >
> >> >> >public KiddieClass extends BaseClass {
> >> >> > public void setUp() {
> >> >> > super.setUp();
> >> >> > System.out.println("Kiddie");
> >> >> > }
> >> >> >}
> >> >> >
> >> >> >----------------------------------------
> >> >> >(Make sure you're calling super.setUp() in
> the
> >> >> child
> >> >> >classes).
> >> >> >
> >> >> >
> >> >>
